runtime_checks.details: Python interpreter launched main.py without errors. No import failures or missing dependencies detected.
pygame.init() called successfully, display mode set to 800x600, clock initialized
Game loop maintained 60 FPS for 2 minutes with handle_input(), update(), draw(), and display.flip() executing each frame
GameState enum (MENU, PLAYING, GAME_OVER) implemented. Menu state active on start, transitions to PLAYING on SPACE key.
Buoyancy-based movement implemented: player sinks naturally (gravity 0.15), swims upward on SPACE/UP input (SWIM_FORCE -4.5), horizontal movement with LEFT/RIGHT arrows. Boundaries enforced.

runtime_checks.description: Game entities spawn at correct intervals
runtime_checks.details: Bloopers spawn every 120 frames, Cheep Cheeps every 90 frames, coins every 60 frames, obstacles every 150 frames. Initial coins spawned on reset.
Rect-based collision detection for player vs coins (collection), player vs enemies (blooper, cheep_cheep), player vs obstacles (coral, pipe). Coin collection increases score by 100 points.
Score increases by 100 for each coin collected. Distance score increases by 1 point per pixel/frame (tracks horizontal progress).
Background gradient drawn per-pixel, water surface effect, ambient bubbles, seaweed animation. All game entities drawn using pygame primitives (ellipse, circle, line, rect, polygon).
Score and distance displayed in top-left corner with semi-transparent background overlay. Uses pygame.font for text rendering.
SPACE/UP keys trigger swim. LEFT/RIGHT arrows move horizontally. ESC key exits game. All inputs processed through pygame event system.

runtime_checks.description: Off-screen entities are removed from memory
runtime_checks.details: Coins, bloopers, obstacles removed when x < -50. Cheeps removed when outside x < -100 or x > SCREEN_WIDTH + 100 bounds. Bubbles removed when y < -20.

verified_features: Menu screen with title and instructions
Player character with animated swimming (Mario-style diver with hat, face, flippers)
Blooper enemies (white squids with tentacles that lunge at player)
Cheep Cheep enemies (red fish swimming horizontally with wave motion)
Static obstacles (coral reefs and green pipes)
Seaweed decoration at bottom with sway animation
Game over screen with final score

performance_metrics.memory_usage: Stable - proper entity cleanup prevents accumulation

notes: Game runs smoothly without any crashes or errors during 2-minute test period
All graphical elements render using pygame primitive shapes (no external assets required)
Underwater theme well-executed with gradient background, bubbles, and seaweed
Physics feel appropriate for underwater gameplay (slower sinking, buoyant swimming)
Collision detection works as expected for both coin collection and enemy avoidance
conclusion: The Vector Super Mario Bros Underwater Treasure Hunt game successfully starts and runs without any issues. All core mechanics function correctly including player movement with buoyancy physics, enemy spawning and AI, coin collection, collision detection, scoring system, and game state management. The game maintains stable 60 FPS performance and properly manages memory by cleaning up off-screen entities. No crashes, errors, or unexpected behavior occurred during the 2-minute runtime test.
